<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assisting-the-client-in-expressing-emotions">Assisting the Client in Expressing Emotions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assisting-the-client-in-expressing-emotions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Teaching about the relationship between stress and physical symptoms is a useful way to help clients begin to see the mind-body relationship. Clients may keep a detailed journal of their physical symptoms. The nurse might ask them to describe the situation at the time such as whether they were alone or with others, whether any disagreements were occurring, and so forth. The journal may help clients see when physical symptoms seemed worse or better and what other factors may have affected that perception.</p>
<p>Limiting the time that clients can focus on physical complaints alone may be necessary. Encouraging them to focus on emotional feelings is important, though this can be difficult for clients. The nurse should provide attention and positive feedback for efforts to identify and discuss</p>
<p>934</p>
<p>feelings.</p>
<p>It may help for the nurse to explain to the family about primary and secondary gains. For example, if the family can provide attention to clients when they are feeling better or fulfilling responsibilities, the clients are more likely to continue doing so. If family members have lavished attention on clients when they have physical complaints, the nurse can encourage the relatives to stop reinforcing the sick role.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="teaching-coping-strategies">Teaching Coping Strategies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#teaching-coping-strategies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two categories of coping strategies are important for clients to learn and to practice: emotion-focused coping strategies, which help clients relax and reduce feelings of stress, and problem-focused coping strategies, which help resolve or change a client's behavior or situation or manage life stressors. Emotion-focused strategies include progressive relaxation, deep breathing, guided imagery, and distractions such as music or other activities. Many approaches to stress relief are available for clients to try. The nurse should help clients learn and practice these techniques, emphasizing that their effectiveness usually improves with routine use. Clients must not expect such techniques to eliminate their pain or physical symptoms; rather, the focus is helping them manage or diminish the intensity of the symptoms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="client-and-family-education">CLIENT AND FAMILY EDUCATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-and-family-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-somatic-symptom-illnesses">For Somatic Symptom Illnesses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-somatic-symptom-illnesses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Establish daily health routine, including adequate rest, exercise, and nutrition.</li>
<li>Teach about relationship of stress and physical symptoms and mind-body relationship.</li>
<li>Educate about proper nutrition, rest, and exercise.</li>
<li>Educate client in relaxation techniques: progressive relaxation, deep breathing, guided imagery, and distraction such as music or other activities.</li>
<li>Educate client by role-playing social situations and interactions.</li>
<li>Encourage family to provide attention and encouragement when client has fewer complaints.</li>
<li>Encourage family to decrease special attention when client is in "sick"</li>
</ul>
<p>935</p>
<p>role.</p>
<p>Problem-focused coping strategies include learning problem-solving methods, applying the process to identified problems, and role-playing interactions with others. For example, a client may complain that no one comes to visit or that she has no friends. The nurse can help the client plan social contact with others, can role-play what to talk about (other than the client's complaints), and can improve the client's confidence in making relationships. The nurse can also help clients identify stressful life situations and plan strategies to deal with them. For example, if a client finds it difficult to accomplish daily household tasks, the nurse can help him to plan a schedule with difficult tasks followed by something the client may enjoy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="evaluation">Evaluation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#evaluation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Somatic symptom illnesses are chronic or recurrent, so changes are likely to occur slowly. If treatment is effective, the client should make fewer visits to physicians as a result of physical complaints, use less medication and more positive coping techniques, and increase functional abilities. Improved family and social relationships are also a positive outcome that may follow improvements in the client's coping abilities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="community-based-care">COMMUNITY-BASED CARE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community-based-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Health care professionals often encounter clients with somatic symptom illnesses in clinics, physicians' offices, or settings other than those related to mental health. Building a trusting relationship with the client, providing empathy and support, and being sensitive to rather than dismissive of complaints are skills that the nurse can use in any setting where clients are seeking assistance. Making appropriate referrals such as to a pain clinic for clients with pain disorder or providing information about support groups in the community may be helpful. Encouraging clients to find pleasurable activities or hobbies may help meet their needs for attention and security, thus diminishing the psychological needs for somatic symptoms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-interventions">NURSING INTERVENTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>937</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="for-somatic-symptom-illnesses">For Somatic Symptom Illnesses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-somatic-symptom-illnesses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Health teaching</li>
<li>Establish a daily routine.</li>
<li>Promote adequate nutrition and sleep.</li>
<li>Expression of emotional feelings</li>
<li>Recognize relationship between stress/coping and physical symptoms.</li>
<li>Keep a journal.</li>
<li>Limit time spent on physical complaints.</li>
<li>Limit primary and secondary gains.</li>
<li>Coping strategies</li>
<li>Emotion-focused coping strategies such as relaxation techniques, deep breathing, guided imagery, and distraction</li>
<li>Problem-focused coping strategies such as problem-solving strategies and role-playing</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mental-health-promotion">MENTAL HEALTH PROMOTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mental-health-promotion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A common theme in somatic symptom illnesses is their occurrence in people who do not express conflicts, stress, and emotions verbally. They express themselves through physical symptoms; the resulting attention and focus on their physical ailments somewhat meet their needs. As these clients are better able to express their emotions and needs directly, physical symptoms subside. Thus, assisting them in dealing with emotional issues directly is a strategy for mental health promotion.</p>
<p>Somatic symptom illnesses have declined over the past few decades, in part due to increased knowledge of the public, increasing self-awareness or self-knowledge, and scientific evidence of mind-body interaction. Some would credit the internet with putting unlimited resources at people's fingertips, and knowledge often precedes understanding and behavior change. Interestingly, there are others who credit the internet accessibility with feeding some peoples' fears about their health—called cyberchondria. Cyberchondria refers to excessive or repeated online searches for health-related information that is distressing or anxiety-provoking for the person (McMullan, Berle, Arnaez, &amp; Starcevic, 2018). The person's anxiety about his or her own health increased as more time is spent online seeking health information.</p>
<p>938</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="best-practice-screening-for-somatic-symptom-disorder">BEST PRACTICE: Screening for Somatic Symptom Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#best-practice-screening-for-somatic-symptom-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Currently, medical personnel consider a somatic illness diagnosis when no other medical diagnosis seems to explain a client's symptoms. The self-reported data from clients and the absence of laboratory or other diagnostic tests are used to determine the existence of somatic illness. By that time, both client and practitioner may be frustrated and emotionally focused on symptoms. Use of a self-report questionnaire as a screening tool can point to a somatic illness diagnosis sooner rather than later as a "last resort."</p>
<p>The next step is to select one of the existing questionnaires and encourage use for screening in medical office settings before frustration and emotion further complicate the client's distress. Framing the client's symptoms as medically undiagnosed may also be beneficial.</p>
<p>Laferton, J. A. C., Stenzel, N. M. Rief, W., Klaus, K., Brähler, E., &amp; Mewes, R. (2017). Screening for DMM-5 somatic symptom disorder: Diagnostic accuracy of self-report measures within a population sample. Psychosomatic Medicine, 79(9), 974–981.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="self-awareness-issues">SELF-AWARENESS ISSUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-awareness-issues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Clients who cope with physical symptoms can be frustrating for the nurse. Initially, they are unwilling to consider that anything other than major physical illness is the root of all their problems. When health professionals tell clients there is no physical illness and refer them to mental health professionals, the response is often anger. Clients may express anger directly or passively at the medical community and be highly critical of the inadequate care they believe they have received. The nurse must not respond with anger to such outbursts or criticism.</p>
<p>The client's progress is slow and painstaking if any change happens at all. Clients coping with somatization have been doing so for years. Changes are not rapid or drastic. The nurse may feel frustrated because after giving the client his or her best efforts, the client returns time after time with the same focus on physical symptoms. The nurse should be realistic about the small successes that can be achieved in any given period. To enhance the ongoing</p>
<p>relationship, the nurse must be able to accept the client and his or her continued complaints and criticisms while remaining nonjudgmental.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-somatoform-disorders">Points to Consider When Working with Clients with Somatoform Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-somatoform-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Carefully assess the client’s physical complaints. Even when a client has a history of a somatoform disorder, the nurse must not dismiss physical complaints or assume they are psychological. The client may indeed have a medical condition.</li>
<li>Validate the client’s feelings while trying to engage him or her in treatment; for example, use a reflective yet engaging comment, such as “I know you’re not feeling well, but it is important to get some exercise each day.”</li>
<li>Remember that the somatic complaints are not under the client’s voluntary control. The client will have fewer somatic complaints when he or she improves coping skills and interpersonal relationships.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-thinking-questions">CRITICAL THINKING QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>When a client has pain disorder, powerful analgesics such as narcotics are generally contraindicated, even though the client is suffering unremitting pain. How might the nurse feel when working with this client? How does the nurse respond when the client says, “You know I’m in pain! Why won’t you do anything? Why do you let me suffer?”</li>
<li>The nurse hears the parent of a client with somatic symptom illness say to a friend, “The doctor just said that there’s nothing physically wrong with Sally. She’s been lying to me about being sick!” How would the nurse approach Sally’s parent? What intervention(s) is/are indicated?</li>
<li>A parent is found to have caused a medical crisis by giving his or her 6-year-old child a medication to which the child has a known severe allergy. The parent is diagnosed as having Munchausen syndrome by proxy. Should the parent be treated in the mental health setting? Should the parent be charged with a criminal act? Why?</li>
</ol>
<p>939</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-points">KEY POINTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Somatization means transforming mental experiences and states into bodily symptoms.</li>
<li>The three central features of somatic symptom illnesses are physical complaints that suggest major medical illness but have no demonstrable organic basis; psychological factors and conflicts that seem important in initiating, exacerbating, and maintaining the symptoms; and symptoms or magnified health concerns that are not under the client’s conscious control.</li>
<li>Somatic symptom illnesses include somatic symptom disorder, conversion disorder, illness anxiety disorder, and pain disorder.</li>
<li>Malingering means feigning physical symptoms for some external gain, such as avoiding work.</li>
<li>Factitious disorders are characterized by physical symptoms that are feigned or inflicted for the sole purpose of drawing attention to oneself and gaining the emotional benefits of assuming the sick role.</li>
<li>MUS and functional somatic syndromes are terms used in general medical practice settings when patients have physical symptoms and/or limitations unexplained by a medical diagnosis.</li>
<li>Internalization and somatization are the chief defense mechanisms seen in clients with somatoform disorders.</li>
<li>Clients with somatic symptom disorder and conversion reactions eventually may be treated in mental health settings. Clients with other somatic symptom illnesses are typically seen in medical settings.</li>
<li>Clients who cope with stress through somatizing are reluctant or unable to identify emotional feelings and interpersonal issues and have few coping abilities unrelated to physical symptoms.</li>
<li>Nursing interventions that may be effective with clients who somatize involve providing health teaching, identifying emotional feelings and stress, and using alternative coping strategies.</li>
<li>Coping strategies that are helpful to clients with somatic symptom illnesses include relaxation techniques such as guided imagery and deep breathing; distractions such as music; and problem-solving strategies such as identifying stressful situations, learning new methods of managing them, and role-playing social interactions.</li>
</ul>
<p>940</p>
<ul>
<li>Clients with somatic symptom disorder actually experience symptoms and the associated discomfort and pain. The nurse should never try to confront the client about the origin of these symptoms until the client has learned other coping strategies.</li>
<li>Somatic symptom illnesses are chronic or recurrent, so progress toward treatment outcomes can be slow and difficult.</li>
<li>Nurses caring for clients with somatic symptom illnesses must show patience and understanding toward them as they struggle through years of recurrent somatic complaints and attempts to learn new emotion- and problem-focused coping strategies.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="references">REFERENCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#references" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="additional-readings">ADDITIONAL READINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-readings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-study-guide">Chapter Study Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-study-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiple-choice-questions">MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-choice-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<ol>
<li>
<p>The nurse is caring for a client with a conversion disorder. Which finding will the nurse expect during assessment?
a. Extreme distress over the physical symptom
b. Indifference about the physical symptom
c. Labile mood
d. Multiple physical complaints</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which statement would indicate that teaching about somatic symptom disorder has been effective?
a. "The doctor believes I am faking my symptoms."
b. "If I try harder to control my symptoms, I will feel better."
c. "I will feel better when I begin handling stress more effectively."
d. "Nothing will help me feel better physically."</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Paroxetine (Paxil) has been prescribed for a client with a somatic symptom illness. The nurse instructs the client to watch out for which side effect?
a. Constipation
b. Increased appetite
c. Increased flatulence
d. Nausea</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emotion-focused coping strategies are designed to accomplish which outcome?
a. Helping the client manage difficult situations more effectively</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>943</p>
<p>b. Helping the client manage the intensity of symptoms
c. Teaching the client the relationship between stress and physical symptoms
d. Relieving the client's physical symptoms</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Which is true about clients with illness anxiety disorder?
a. They may interpret normal body sensations as signs of disease.
b. They often exaggerate or fabricate physical symptoms for attention.
c. They do not show signs of distress about their physical symptoms.
d. All of the above.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The client's family asks the nurse, "What is illness anxiety disorder?"
The best response by the nurse is, "Illness anxiety disorder is
a. a persistent preoccupation with getting a serious disease."
b. an illness not fully explained by a diagnosed medical condition."
c. characterized by a variety of symptoms over a number of years."
d. the eventual result of excessive worrying about diseases."</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client with somatic symptom disorder has been attending group therapy. Which statement indicates therapy is having a positive outcome for this client?
a. "I feel better physically just from getting a chance to talk."
b. "I haven't said much, but I get a lot from listening to others."
c. "I shouldn't complain too much; my problems aren't as bad as others."
d. "The other people in this group have emotional problems."</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A client who developed numbness in the right hand could not play the piano at a scheduled recital. The consequence of the symptom, not having to perform, is best described as
a. emotion-focused coping.
b. phobia.
c. primary gain.
d. secondary gain.</p>
</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-example">CLINICAL EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mary Jones, 34 years old, was referred to a chronic pain clinic with a diagnosis of pain disorder. She has been unable to work for 7 months because of back pain. Mary has seen several doctors, has had magnetic resonance imaging, and has tried various antiinflammatory medications. She tells the nurse she is at the clinic as a last resort because none of her doctors will "do anything" for her. Mary's gait is slow, her posture is stiff, and she grimaces frequently while trying to sit in a chair. She reports being unable to drive a car, play with her children, do housework, or enjoy any of her previous leisure activities.</p>
<ol>
<li>Identify three nursing diagnoses that would be pertinent for Mary's plan of care.</li>
</ol>
<p>945</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Identify two expected outcomes for Mary’s plan of care.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Describe five interventions that the nurse might implement to achieve the outcomes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What other disciplines might make a contribution to Mary’s care at the clinic?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Identify any community referrals the nurse might make for Mary.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>946</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-22">CHAPTER 22<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-22" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="neurodevelopmental-disorders">Neurodevelopmental Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurodevelopmental-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
autism spectrum disorder (ASD)</p>
<ul>
<li>encopresis</li>
<li>enuresis</li>
<li>sluggish cognitive tempo (SCT)</li>
<li>stereotyped motor behavior</li>
<li>therapeutic play
